dict.string: F8185949-BE2C-4ECB-A9CA-C6E8E2B7E14B
http://www.infoworld.com/article/2920333/mobile-development/swift-vs-objective-c-10-reasons-the-future-favors-swift.html
no more @ symbol
drops legacy conventions,no longer need semicolons.
method calls, do not nest inside each other resulting in bracket hell -- bye-bye, [[[ ]]]
Swift code more closely resembles natural English, This readability makes it easier for existing programmers from JavaScript, Java, Python, C#, and C++ to adopt Swift into their tool chain
1. Swift is easier to read
drops the two-file requirement
2. Swift is easier to maintain(容易维护)
Optional types make the possibility of a nil optional value very clear in Swift code, which means it can generate a compiler error as you write bad code
2ADBD3FF-26FE-455E-AFF3-EF26E35508A4
To provide predictable behavior Swift triggers a runtime crash if a nil optional variable is used.
3. Swift is safer
F0BEAFB1-32F2-4B0C-8E32-1CA20CAD09B8
Swift unifies the language in a way that Objective-C never has.
for procedural C code and APIs like Core Graphics. and other low-level APIs available on iOS.
The huge memory leaks that a programmer can have in Objective-C are impossible in Swift.

Because ARC in Swift works across both procedural and object-oriented code, it requires no more mental context switches for programmers, even as they write code that touches lower-level APIs -- a problem with the current version of Objective-C
4. Swift is unified with memory management
540BAC08-CCF0-4EF9-AB9B-F2557DA1DCA6
Support for combining characters and strings like this is fundamental for any programming language that displays text to a user on a screen.
Support for + inline support for manipulating text strings and data
5. Swift requires less code

Swift is nearly on par with C++ for both the FFT and Mandelbrot algorithms. According to Primate Labs, the GEMM algorithm performance suggests the Swift compiler cannot vectorize code the C++ compiler can -- an easy performance gain that could be achieved in the next version of Swift.
6. Swift is faster
5D9ADCBB-789B-4FD9-8D30-A953AA8DFF17
With Swift, namespaces are based on the target that a code file belongs to. This means programmers can differentiate classes or values using the namespace identifier
A749A4EE-BFE0-4E9C-9FED-9703E544D09F
This change in Swift is huge. It greatly facilitates incorporating open source projects, frameworks, and libraries into your code.
7. Fewer name collisions with open source projects
This means Swift can evolve faster than iOS, which is a requirement for a modern programming language.

Dynamic libraries are external to the app executable, but are included within the app bundle downloaded from the App Store. It reduces the initial size of an app as it is loaded into memory, since the external code is linked only when used.
Dynamic libraries have never been supported on iOS until the launch of Swift and iOS 8, even though dynamic libraries have been supported on Mac for a very long time.
8. Swift supports dynamic libraries
9. Swift Playgrounds encourages interactive coding
10. Swift is a future you can influence
10 reasons the future favors Swift
Swift vs. Objective-C
Swift vs. Objective-C
